parks.fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park
parks.description: For over a century people from around the world have come to rural Central Kentucky to honor the humble beginnings of our 16th president, Abraham Lincoln. His early life on Kentucky's frontier shaped his character and prepared him to lead the nation through Civil War. The country's first memorial to Lincoln, built with donations from young and old, enshrines the symbolic birthplace cabin.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee associated with visiting either unit of the park.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

parks.directionsInfo: The Birthplace Unit of the park is located approximately 2 miles south of the town of Hodgenville on U.S. Highway 31E South. The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek is located approximately 10 miles northeast of the Birthplace Unit of the park.

operatingHours.description:
The Memorial Building is open 9:00 am - 4:30 pm eastern time with a limited viewing area.  The Visitor Center and grounds of the Birthplace Unit are open 9:00 am - 5:00 pm eastern time with one-way traffic flow and social distancing.


The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek will be closed August 3, 2020, to July 31, 2021, due to the Lincoln Tavern Rehabilitation Project.
operatingHours.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park

images.title: The Memorial Building with fall colors
images.altText: The Memorial Building surrounded by fall colors
images.caption: Over 200,000 people a year come to walk up the steps of the Memorial Building to visit the site where Abraham Lincoln was born

images.title: The Memorial Building
images.altText: The first memorial erected to honor Abraham Lincoln
images.caption: The Memorial Building constructed on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: The Symbolic Birth Cabin of Abraham Lincoln
images.altText: The symbolic birth cabin on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
images.caption: The symbolic birth cabin of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: Statue of the Lincoln Family in the Visitor Center
images.altText: Statue of the Lincoln family in the park's Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors to the park can view the statue of the Lincoln family.

parks.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Central Kentucky. However, temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer is usually hot and humid. Winter is moderately cold with mixed precipitation.
parks.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace

parks.description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

entranceFees.description: This fee includes all occupants of a private, non-commercial vehicle and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Per Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one motorcycle; valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one individual walking in or bicycling in and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Individual

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 15 or less pay a per vehicle fee.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity 15 or less

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 16 or more pay a $12.00 per person fee. Children 15 and younger are free. Annual and lifetime passes may be used.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity of 16 or more

entranceFees.description: $12 per client; passes may not be used. Business is required to obtain commercial use authorization. Bus tours, 25 person capacity or greater, $200 (commercial use authorization not required).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group Fee

entrancePasses.description: The Big Bend Annual Pass covers entrance fees to Big Bend National Park. Pass is available at Big Bend National Park entrance stations or the Panther Junction Visitor Center. Pass is non-transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Big Bend Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Several highways lead to Big Bend National Park: TX 118 from Alpine to Study Butte or FM 170 from Presidio to Study Butte (then 26 miles east to park headquarters) or US 90 or US 385 to Marathon (then 70 miles south to park headquarters). Distances between towns and services are considerable. Be sure you have plenty of gas, food, water, and supplies for your trip.

operatingHours.description: Big Bend National Park is always open. You can enter and exit at any time of the day or night. Park entrances are open 24 hours daily, all year.
operatingHours.name: Big Bend National Park

images.title: Blooming Cenizo
images.altText: Blooming Cenizo
images.caption: Cenizo, or Big Bend Silverleaf blossoms after summer rains.

images.title: Century Plant Agave
images.altText: Century Plant Agave
images.caption: Century Plants bloom only once in their long lives.

images.title: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.altText: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.caption: Big Bend is home to over 450 species of birds!

images.title: Fascinating Geology
images.altText: Fascinating Geology
images.caption: Volcanic features abound near Castolon

images.title: Desert Scenery
images.altText: Desert Scenery
images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

images.title: Santa Elena Canyon
images.altText: Santa Elena Canyon
images.caption: Santa Elena Canyon

images.title: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.altText: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.caption: Big Bend is a place of expansive views

images.title: Rio Grande Scene
images.altText: Rio Grande Scene
images.caption: The Rio Grande serves as the park's southern boundary

images.title: Blooming Ocotillo
images.altText: Blooming Ocotillo
images.caption: When ocotillo bloom, they transform the desert

images.title: Balanced Rock
images.altText: Balanced Rock
images.caption: The balanced rock is a popular day hiking destination.

images.title: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.altText: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.caption: Hiking the Lost Mine Trail affords many amazing views.

images.title: Chisos Mountains
images.altText: Chisos Mountains
images.caption: The Chisos Mountains rise above the desert

parks.weatherInfo: Big Bend is a desert park, so be prepared for extreme conditions. SPRING: From February through April the park abounds with pleasant and comfortable temperatures. SUMMER: May through September is very hot. Temperatures will exceed 100 degrees in the lower elevations by late morning, and often exceed 110 along the Rio Grande. Afternoon thunderstorms can be a welcome respite. WINTER: October through January temperatures are cooler; the weather can quickly turn cold at any time during these months.
parks.name: Big Bend

parks.fullName: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
parks.description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed 1840s adobe fur trading post on the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade. Today, living historians recreate the sights, sounds, and smells of the past with guided tours, demonstrations and special events.

entranceFees.description: The fee allows visitors to experience the fort and its rooms and meet and visit with period-clothed interpreters. It is a per person charge.  Payment allows the holder to visit the site for one day on the date of purchase. The park collects a Living History fee of $3 for adults, $2 for 6-12 year olds with children under 6 years age free. The park collects a $5 person event fee (fee subject to change) for anyone 6 years or older during major events. Fees are collected at the fort. Credit cards are preferred.
entranceFees.title: Bent's Old Fort Living History Fee

entrancePasses.description: The fee allows visitors to experience the fort and its rooms and meet and visit with period-clothed interpreters. It is a per person charge.  Payment allows the holder to visit the site for one day on the date of purchase. The park collects a Living History fee of $3 for adults, $2 for 6-12 year olds with children under 6 years age free. The park collects a $5 person event fee (fee subject to change) for anyone 6 years or older during major events. Fees are collected at the fort. Credit cards are preferred.
entrancePasses.title: Bent's Old Fort Living History Fee

parks.directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 109 north 1 mile to Colorado Highway 194, then east on Colorado Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours (Memorial Day Weekend to Indigenous Peoples' Day)
The fort is open from 8:00 am to 5:30 pm. The gate is open from 7:00 am to 5:30 pm.

Winter Hours (the day after Indigenous Peoples' Day to the day before Memorial Day Weekend)
The fort is open from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day, when the fort will be closed. The gate is open from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort in background with wagon in front; fall yellow cottonwood leaves in foreground
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie in foreground and blue sky and clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Open hearth cooking in the fort kitchen
images.altText: Cooking in fort kitchen
images.caption: Buffalo meat is broiled in the reflector oven as was done historically in the 1840s.

images.title: Fur trapper explains the work of the 1830s.
images.altText: Fur trapper in camp
images.caption: Special events bring the past alive with encampments, fort trade and Plains Indian life.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie, tepee and wagon in foreground and blue sky & clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: A Lakota warrior barters with the traders in the fort plaza
images.altText: Plains Indian trade in plaza
images.caption: Trade with a Lakota warrior for trade goods from around the world.

images.title: Swivel cannon is fired using 18th century drill
images.altText: Swivel cannon firing
images.caption: The fort's security depended on its ability to resist attack.

images.title: Hiking the Santa Fe Trail
images.altText: HIkers follow behind the fort's wagon on the Santa Fe Trail
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail Encampment features a hike with the fort's wagon down the original Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Santa Fe Trail Encampment and Trail Hike
images.altText: Interpreters and volunteers in period clothing on horseback and in wagons; group of people standing
images.caption: The Park features the Santa Fe Trail Encampment during certain years. Historical interpreters bring the fort to life. Visitors can hike 3 miles down the original Santa Fe Trail with the fort's wagons.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures are are often in the high 90s and low 100s. Weather is generally fair in the fall and spring. Winter temperatures can be below freezing. Most of the fort is unheated and does not have modern cooling systems, so dress accordingly.
parks.name: Bent's Old Fort

parks.description: Want to live on the edge? Visit a place recreated each day by ocean wind and waves. Life on Assateague Island has adapted to an existence on the move. Explore sandy beaches, salt marshes, maritime forests and coastal bays. Rest, relax, recreate and enjoy some time on the edge of the continent.

entranceFees.description: Entrance into Assateague Island National Seashore (MD) & Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA). Valid for 7 days. Purchased at Assateague Island National Seashore (MD) and the Toms Cove Visitor Center (VA).
entranceFees.title: Assateague Island National Seashore Weekly Vehicle Pass

entranceFees.description:
Entrance into Assateague Island National Seashore (MD) & Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA). Valid for 7 days.
Purchased at the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA).
entranceFees.title: Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge Weekly Vehicle Pass

entranceFees.description: Entrance into Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA). Valid for 1 day. Purchased at the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA).
entranceFees.title: Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge Daily Vehicle Pass

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 1 year from month of purchase for entry to Assateague Island National Seashore (MD) and Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA). Purchased at Assateague Island National Seashore (MD) and the Toms Cove Visitor Center (VA).
entrancePasses.title: Assateague Island National Seashore Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 1 year from month of purchase for entry to Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA) and Island National Seashore (MD). Purchased at the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA).
entrancePasses.title: Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge Annual Beach Parking Permit combined with the Federal Duck Stamp (valid for 1 year, July 1 to June 30, at all National Wildlife Refuges) will gain entry into Assateague Island National Seashore (MD) and Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA) for 1 vehicle.  Purchased at the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (VA).
entrancePasses.title: Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge Annual Beach Parking Permit

parks.directionsInfo: There are two entrances to Assateague Island National Seashore. Assateague's north entrance is at the end of Route 611, eight miles south of Ocean City, MD. The south entrance is at the end of Route 175, two miles east of Chincoteague, VA. There is no vehicle access between the two entrances on Assateague Island. Vehicles must return to the mainland to access either the north or south entrance.

operatingHours.description: Open year round, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Assateague Island National Seashore - Maryland District

operatingHours.description:
Open January-February: 6 am - 6 pm.
March 15-April: 6 am - 8 pm.
May-September 15: 5 am - 10 pm.
September 15-October: 6 am - 8 pm.
November-December: 6 am - 6 pm.
Check with the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge (757-336-6122) for updates to operating hours.
operatingHours.name: Assateague Island National Seashore - Virginia District

images.title: Wild Horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.altText: Wild horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.caption: There are few places in the United States where you can view wild horses.Take advantage of the opportunity to view these horses in a natural habitat.

images.title: Wild horses in the salt marshes on Assateague Island
images.altText: Wild horses in the salt marshes on Assateague Island
images.caption: Assateague's wild horses can often be found grazing in salt marshes.

images.title: Tree Swallows Migrating along Assateague
images.altText: Tree Swallows migrating along the beach at Assateague
images.caption: Enormous flocks of migrating tree swallows stop and rest on Assateague beaches in the fall.

images.title: Camping at Assateague
images.altText: tents and vehicle in the oceanside campground dunes
images.caption: Tent camping in the Oceanside campground at Assateague is a great way to relax and recreate at the beach.

images.title: Waves on Assateague beach
images.altText: waves on Assateague beach with people fishing in the background
images.caption: Visit the shifting sands at the water's edge where thousands of waves change the beach every day.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Often windy and cool with lows in the 40's and highs in the 60's. Summer: Hot and humid with lows in the 60's and highs in the 80's. Fall: Warm with lows in the 50's and highs in the 70's. Winter: Damp cold and often windy. Lows in the 20's, highs in the 40's.
parks.name: Assateague Island

parks.description: Andrew Johnson's complex presidency (1865-69) illustrates the Constitution at work following the Civil War. As the President and Congress disagreed on Reconstruction methods, the Constitution served as their guide on balance of powers, vetoes, and impeachment. In the end, it evolved as a living document with pivotal amendments on freedom, citizenship, and voting rights - topics still vital today.

entranceFees.description: All areas of the site are free, but tickets are required for the Presidential Homestead tour. These tickets are available at the Visitor Center.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

entrancePasses.description: As the Andrew Johnson National Historic Site is free, there is no distribution of or need for annual passes.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance passes not available

parks.directionsInfo: GPS The GPS setting for Andrew Johnson NHS may be listed as 121 Monument Ave, which is the park HQ in the National Cemetery. To arrive at the Visitor Center, use 101 North College Street, Greeneville, TN. Plane The closest airport is the Tri-Cities Regional Airport, 43 miles NE of Greeneville. From the airport, take I-81 South to exit 36 and follow the signs to Greeneville. Car From I-81S take exit 36 to Rt. 172 south to Greeneville. From I-81N take exit 23 to Rt. 11E north to Greeneville.

operatingHours.description:
The Andrew Johnson NHS has transitioned to summer hours. The site is currently open from 9:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. daily. 

The historic Andrew Johnson Homestead offers free daily guided tours of the historic Andrew Johnson Homestead at 10:30 a.m., 11:30 a.m., 1:30 p.m., and 2:30 p.m. For visitor safety, the guided tours are limited to 10 participants. Tickets are available at the Visitor Center up to fifteen minutes before tour time.
operatingHours.name: Andrew Johnson National Historic Site

images.title: Andrew Johnson Homestead
images.altText: Andrew Johnson Homestead with irises and flag
images.caption: Home of the 17th President from 1851-1875

images.title: Early Home
images.altText: Andrew Johnson's Early Home
images.caption: The Johnson family home from the 1830s - 1851

images.title: Andrew Johnson Monument
images.altText: Andrew Johnson Monument
images.caption: Gravestone of President and Mrs. Andrew Johnson

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: The entrance sidewalk to the Visitor Center with the Memorial Building in view
images.caption: The entrance to the Visitor Center

images.title: The Lodge - Park Headquarters
images.altText: A view of the lodge with flag and sky behind
images.caption: The old caretaker's Lodge in the National Cemetery now serves as Park Headquarters

images.title: Andrew Johnson Museum
images.altText: A view of the museum with center case and wall exhibits
images.caption: The Museum tells the story of a controversial presidency

images.title: The National Cemtery
images.altText: A view of Monument Hill studded with veteran headstones
images.caption: The commanding view of Monument Hill with veteran headstones

parks.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in East Tennessee, but temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer and Winter ranges can be extreme. The President's Homestead is not climate controlled and may be closed at times during excessive highs or lows in the summer and winter.
parks.name: Andrew Johnson

parks.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
parks.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.

entranceFees.description: There are NO USER OR ENTRY FEES fees for the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail. NOMINAL FEES may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please visit Plan Your Visit / Places To Go for an interactive map and extensive list of places to visit by state. Contact information is available for each site to call and find out about fees.
entranceFees.title: General Entrance Fee Information

parks.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

parks.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
parks.name: Trail Of Tears

parks.description: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C. The parkway has carried visitors to and from the capital city since 1954.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to the Baltimore Washington Parkway
entranceFees.title: Entrance fee

parks.directionsInfo: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C

operatingHours.description: The Baltimore Washington Parkway is always open.
operatingHours.name: Baltimore Washington Parkway

images.title: Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.altText: Gladys Noon Spellman sign on the Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.caption: The parkway is dedicated for Gladys Noon Spellman

images.title: Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.altText: Greenbelt-Road overpass on the Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.caption: Millions enjoy the scenic entryway to the Nation's Capital

images.title: Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.altText: Baltimore Washington Parkway
images.caption: Baltimore Washington Parkway

parks.weatherInfo: The Washington, D.C. area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Spring: During these months of transition, the weather can alternate from warm, humid air coming from the south to cold, dry air coming from the northwest. Be prepared for changing conditions. Summer: The warmest months are June, July, and August, with average highs in the 80s (~31 ?) combined with high humidity. Temperatures often climb into the 90s (~34?).
parks.name: Baltimore-Washington

parks.fullName: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area
parks.description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for Big South Fork NRRA.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Please use the following link to learn more about how to get here from various locations.

images.title: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.altText: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.caption: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall

parks.weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
parks.name: Big South Fork

parks.description: Come experience mountains and canyons, desert and dunes, night skies and spectacular vistas within a place unlike any other. Guadalupe Mountains National Park protects the world's most extensive Permian fossil reef, the four highest peaks in Texas, an environmentally diverse collection of flora and fauna, and the stories of lives shaped through conflict, cooperation and survival.

entranceFees.description:
An entrance fee of $10 per person (16 years of age and older) is required; entrance fees/passes permit 1-7 consecutive days of use in this national park..

Holders of the Annual, Senior, Military, 4th grade and Access Pass can bring in 3 adults free of charge under their pass. Any pass must be displayed in a vehicle while in the national park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for entrance into Guadalupe Mountains National Park for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits up to four adults in a private vehicle and is non-transferable; visitors under 16 years of age are free. You can purchase this pass at the Pine Springs Visitor Center.
entrancePasses.title: Guadalupe Mountains National Park Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Guadalupe Mountains National Park is located on the north side of US Hwy 62/180. If you are traveling east from El Paso, TX, we are 110 miles East of the city. Follow US Hwy 62/180 North to the Pine Springs Visitor Center. If you are traveling from Van Horn, TX, you will travel north on US 54 and make a left hand turn at the junction of US 62/180 to arrive at the park. If you are traveling west from Carlsbad, NM, you will travel on US Hwy 62/180 South and cross into Texas. Follow signs to the park.

operatingHours.description: The Pine Springs area, including the campground, visitor center, trailhead, and associated parking areas are open and accessible all of the time during normal operations. Camping is permitted in designated campsites only.
operatingHours.name: Pine Springs

operatingHours.description:
Located on the remote west side of the park, these striking dunes cover nearly 2,000 acres. The Salt Basin Dunes are designated day use only and are accessible for visitation beginning at sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset. Camping is specifically prohibited.

The surface of the access road is clay. During rainy weather, the road becomes dangerously slippery; it is unsafe to travel when wet. The speed limit is 25 miles per hour. Watch for livestock on the roadway.
operatingHours.name: Salt Basin Dunes

operatingHours.description: McKittrick Canyon is designated as day-use only, with visiting hours from 8:00 AM - 6:00 PM, April through October (Mountain Daylight Time), and 8:00 AM - 4:30 PM, November through March (Mountain Standard Time). Please exit McKittrick Canyon before the posted closing time. The entrance gate on U.S.Highway 62/180 is locked each evening.
operatingHours.name: McKittrick Canyon

operatingHours.description: The Frijole Ranch Road provides access to the Frijole Horse Campsites, the Frijole Ranch History Museum, and the associated trailhead. A picnic area is located at the end of the road. Camping is permitted in designated campsites only.
operatingHours.name: Frijole Ranch

operatingHours.description: Dog Canyon lies in a secluded, forested canyon on the north end of the park at an elevation of 6,300 feet. Remote and far removed from civilization; it stands at the edge of the wilderness boundary, and offers an ideal location for quiet camping, birding, hiking, and solitude. A visitor center, trailhead, and campground are available. The Dog Canyon district is open all day during normal park operations.
operatingHours.name: Dog Canyon

images.title: El Capitan
images.altText: El Capitan with blooming claret cup cacti
images.caption: Blossoming claret cup cacti add a splash of color to the Chihuahuan desert.

images.title: Flooded Salt Flats
images.altText: the slat flats become flooded during monsoon months after large rain events.
images.caption: After the monsoon storms, the salt flats will often become flooded creating a seasonal lake.

images.title: Devil's Hall Fall Colors
images.altText: Fall colors in Devil's Hall
images.caption: Changing maple trees line the Devil's Hall trail during the fall months.

images.title: Pratt Cabin
images.altText: Pratt Cabin in McKittrick Canyon
images.caption: Pratt Cabin is nestled in McKittrick Canyon with abundant trees and

images.title: The Bowl wildflowers
images.altText: wildflowers blossom along The Bowl trail
images.caption: During the spring months, wildflowers are a common sight along The Bowl trail.

images.title: Entrance Sign
images.altText: A metal and stone entrance sign stands in front of a building and desert mountains
images.caption: Entrance sign at Pine Springs

parks.weatherInfo: The Guadalupe Mountains are known for high winds year-round; gusts can reach 60MPH or higher. In winter the mountains experiences occasional, light snowfalls which seldom last more than a day. From May through October, temperatures vary with highs between 80F-100F+ with lows in the 40F-60F range. November to April is generally milder with highs in between 50F-70F with lows in the 30F-50F range. Elevations above 8,000’ will be about 10F cooler than headquarters, with corresponding wind-chill.
parks.name: Guadalupe Mountains
